harmony.contactUtilizationMethod: Grip the iron by wrapping fingers around its handle, point the metal tip forward, press the tip downward onto the table surface, and perform short forward-backward sliding motions while maintaining a slight downward force.
harmony.substrateUtilizationMethod: Rest the ball on the table directly in front of the iron tip, then roll the iron tip over the crest of the ball and back during each stroke so it ascends and descends the curved surface.
harmony.expectedHapticFeedback: Cut the steak with a knife. When slicing through the steak, the sawing motion creates rhythmic resistance pulses.
harmony.explanation: The ball easily rolls away and is difficult to realign under the tip, so haptic contact often misses when the knife visually meets the steak.

harmony.explanation: Riding across the key teeth can produce small bumps, but the key’s narrow width makes it easy to miss, so contact is only moderately reliable.

expressivity.physicalContactObject: clear 30 cm plastic ruler with metric markings
expressivity.physicalSubstrateObject: small black and silver electric iron with coiled power cord
expressivity.contactUtilizationMethod: Hold the ruler about one-third from one end between thumb and index finger, direct the longer section forward, dip the far end toward the surface, lift and tilt back while moving the hand toward the mouth area, and perform small stirring wrist circles.
expressivity.substrateUtilizationMethod: Set the unplugged iron upside-down so the metal soleplate faces upward, steadying the handle with the coiled cord tucked aside. Dip the far end of the ruler onto the smooth soleplate and rotate the wrist in small circles while keeping the ruler’s tip in contact with the curved surface.
expressivity.expectedHapticFeedback: Stir the soup with a spoon. When stirring the soup, users should feel smooth, continuous resistance as the spoon moves through liquid.
expressivity.explanation: Uniform metal-on-metal contact yields very little variation in resistance and no fluid‐like drag, so it fails to convey the continuous viscosity of soup.

expressivity.substrateUtilizationMethod: Turn the keyboard so the long edge is perpendicular to your stroke, rest it flat, and drive the mouse’s front edge across the top of an entire key row so each key press and release provides a rapid series of bumps.
expressivity.expectedHapticFeedback: Cut the steak with a knife. When slicing through the steak, the sawing motion creates rhythmic resistance pulses.
expressivity.explanation: Key presses yield many quick bumps but are too uniform and high‐frequency to convincingly emulate the slower, more forceful pulses of slicing through meat.

realism.physicalContactObject: clear 30 cm plastic ruler with metric markings
realism.physicalSubstrateObject: small black and silver electric iron with coiled power cord
realism.contactUtilizationMethod: Hold the ruler about one-third from one end between thumb and index finger, direct the longer section forward, dip the far end toward the surface, lift and tilt back while moving the hand toward the mouth area, and perform small stirring wrist circles.
realism.substrateUtilizationMethod: Set the unplugged iron upside-down so the metal soleplate faces upward, steadying the handle with the coiled cord tucked aside. Dip the far end of the ruler onto the smooth soleplate and rotate the wrist in small circles while keeping the ruler’s tip in contact with the curved surface.
realism.expectedHapticFeedback: Stir the soup with a spoon. When stirring the soup, users should feel smooth, continuous resistance as the spoon moves through liquid.
realism.explanation: Smooth dry metal-on-plastic sliding feels little like fluid drag—very low continuous resistance and no viscosity.

realism.substrateUtilizationMethod: Rest the keyboard flat on the desk. Position the ruler tip between two adjacent keycaps and push downward so the key switches travel and the edge settles between the moving caps.

realism.explanation: Key switches travel only a few millimeters with a sharp spring and click, lacking the deeper, smoother progression of meat penetration.
